newsitem.title: LEBANON: Lebanon C-Bank cuts '96 growth forecast to 3-4 pct.
newsitem.headline: Lebanon C-Bank cuts '96 growth forecast to 3-4 pct.

text.p: Lebanon's economic growth will fall to three or four percent in 1996 from an earlier-expected 7.5 percent, Riad Salameh, Governor of the Bank of Lebanon, said in remarks published on Friday.
Salameh told the bi-monthly French-language magazine Le Commerce du Levant the central bank "believed that the growth rate for this year will range between three to four percent".

Last month, central bank deputy governor Nasser Saidi said the central bank had estimated growth to be 7-7.5 percent but, due to a 17-day Israeli onslaught on Lebanon in April, cut the estimate to 4-4.5 percent.
Lebanon's estimated gross domestic product (GDP) growth in 1995 was seven percent.
In April, Israel launched a blitz against pro-Iranian Hizbollah (Party of God) guerrillas, killing 200 people, mostly civilians, and damaging homes, businesses and infrastructure.
